instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 won't go to sleep
threads.message: Tried other Battery indicator light in a different case.  R6961 is there and has continuity.  I get 3.4v on pin 5 of J6955 whether it's open or closed.  Does that mean the other battery indicator light board is bad as well?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 won't go to sleep
threads.message: Just short R6961 to GND and see if board goes to sleep. Most probable issue would be a damaged J6955 or trace.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 won't go to sleep
threads.message: if I short to ground it does not go to sleep.  resistance from pin 5 of j6955 to pin 1 of R5071 is 103 ohms, so the trace to the SMC is good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 won't go to sleep
threads.message:
resistance from pin 5 of j6955 to pin 1 of R5071 is 103 ohms, so the trace to the SMC is good.

How does that proof the trace to the SMC is good? Diode mode on pin 2 of R6961 would be the proper measurement to verify that.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 won't go to sleep
threads.message:
well, trace from pin 5 throug r6961 to pin 1 of r5071 was good.
reflowed the SMC and now it sleeps. My thinking was the ball for smc lid was cracked. Thanks for the help Duke.
